title: Serif
content:
font id?

thanks!!!!

| [AuRevoir\_750×500\_22.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/typophile.com/files/AuRevoir_750%C3%97500_22.jpg) | 14.97 KB |
author: martipoirier

comments.content:
Art direction attributed to Alberto Moreu c/o [Think Work Observe](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/t-wo.it/2014/06/13/aurevoir-magazine-ss14) so maybe bespoke by TWO and exclusive for the magazine.  
Some alternatives: Radim Peško's [Larish Neue (less Larish Alte)](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/www.radimpesko.com/), [Colophon](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/www.colophon-foundry.org/) Fortescue and Value Serif, [Optimo](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/optimo.ch/) Stanley, Markus John's [Rasmus](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/tendollarfonts.com/products/rasmus) and Philippe Hermann's [GZA](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/fontseek.info/)

If you read the magazine [http://issuu.com/aurevoirmagazine/docs/aurevoir\_n1\_single](http://web.archive.org/web/20150128232616/http:/issuu.com/aurevoirmagazine/docs/aurevoir_n1_single "http://issuu.com/aurevoirmagazine/docs/aurevoir\_n1\_single") you will note that this lettering is used only for the title. The body text is in something more conventional.  
The models are also conventional -- starved waifs.  
As for the lettering, I suggest that Larish Neue is the closest. It has the distinctive serif treatment and a similar look and feel.  
Don
